introduction.p: Because ~(\sqrt{a})(\sqrt{a})=a,~ it is also true that ~\dfrac{a}{\sqrt{a}}= \sqrt{a}.

statement.p:
Simplify. Do not use a calculator!
(\sqrt{7})(\sqrt{7})
\sqrt{n}(\sqrt{n})

solution.p:
By the definition of square root, \sqrt{a} is a number whose square is a.
(\sqrt{7})(\sqrt{7})=7
\sqrt{n}(\sqrt{n})=n

statement.p:
Simplify. Do not use a calculator!
(\sqrt[3]{5})^3
(\sqrt[3]{4})(\sqrt[3]{4})(\sqrt[3]{4})

solution.p:
By the definition of cube root, \sqrt[3]{a} is a number whose cube is a.
(\sqrt[3]{5})^3=5
(\sqrt[3]{4})(\sqrt[3]{4})(\sqrt[3]{4})=4

introduction.p: Rational numbers are the integers and common fractions; we can represent them precisely in decimal form. But the best we can do for an irrational number is to write an approximate decimal form by rounding.

ol.label: a
ol.li: Irrational: ~\sqrt{6}~ is not the quotient of two integers.

li.p: Rational: ~\dfrac{-5}{3}~ is the quotient of two integers.

solution.p:
Use a calculator to evaluate.
Enter ~5~ \boxed{\sqrt{}}~ and round to three decimal places: ~8.660
Enter ~\boxed{(-)}~2~\boxed{\sqrt{}}~21~\boxed{)}~\boxed{\div}~3~ and round to three decimal places: ~-3.055
Enter ~2~\boxed{(+)}~\boxed{\text{MATH}}~\boxed{4}~5~ and round to three decimal places: ~3.710

introduction.p: In the order of operations, simplifying radicals comes after what's inside parentheses (or fraction bars) and before products and quotients.

li.p: We start by simplifying the numerator.
li.me: \begin{aligned}[t] \dfrac{4-\sqrt{64}}{2} \amp = \dfrac{4-8}{2} \amp\amp \blert{\text{Evaluate the radical, then subtract.}}\\ \amp = \dfrac{-4}{2}=-2 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Reduce the fraction.}} \end{aligned}
